titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VII. Heard Baker. 2. Corinthians 5.17. and afternoon, 2. Corinthians 6.1. Visits from D. Webster and G. Blake— Also from G. Hay, who asked me if it was true that the Vice-Presidency had been offered me— Jos. Coolidge, Mr Pedrick and Van Wyck brother of the member dined with us— Johnson Hellen here.

2. VII. Talbot here— D’Wolfe and Dodge— Cheves and Seawell to consult about the proceedings of the Slave indemnity commission. Whether to wait any longer for more evidence of the average value— And whether to admit any on the British side? I advised both— T. Hughes at the Office. And O’Sullivan— His complaint against Forbes— Hicks for Letters to Mexico— Coxe, for Commission as Consul at Tunis— Genl. Jackson, with a Coll Tutt whom he recommends for an Appointment— G. Sullivan. Perplexed how to proceed with the claim—indecisive— Addington—for news and the rolled iron case— At the President’s— Dined at Mosher’s, in Georgetown.

3. VII. Coll. R. M. Johnson here— Working against a Caucus— For Luckett. B. O. Tyler— W. Plumer— New-Hampshire objections to signing the anti-caucus declaration— Little, with W. Loney, J. Loney and W. W. Wilson here— Judge Johnson—for a Court-house at Charleston— Blake—with him to the Office— His Letters gone— H. Baldwin, from Pittsburgh— John Mason jr. anxious to go to Mexico— Fuller—had been at [symbols][P.U.S.] Edwards and Dallas. Conway—About Miller’s Commission— At the President’s, but he was out. Meeting of Trustees of Presbyterian Church till near 7. Payment of Note and Collections— Elizabeth Cranch and Ann M’Knight here— Tuesday Evening party here. About 150— Hail and Snow.

4. VII. G. Hay here— Slave average value papers— Asked if what I had said to him on Sunday was Confidential— It was— Ingham. Full Explanation with him— Hicks at the Office—Gave him a Letter from Wilcocks at Mexico. Drawing room— Mrs Adams did not go. Judges there. When I came home, found J. W. Taylor— J. B. Thomas’s proposals to him.

5. VII. G. Hay here. More Slave average value papers. Bailey. Sloane tells him the Committee of Elections will report against him. The motives! At the Office— Bradley. Coalition of Clay and Calhoun. Project of the Convention at Harrisburg for 4. March. Clay— Calhoun or Jackson— At [symbols][P.U.S.] Southard there just from Trenton. Company to dine and Evening.

6. VII. Meeting of Commissioners of the sinking fund at the Capitol. Marshall, Tompkins, Wirt and myself with Nourse— Annual Report— In the Senate— At the Supreme Court. Emmett speaking on the Steam boat case. In the House— Internal improvements. Smyth, Gazlay, Neal— Conversation with Members— J. W. Taylor— Declaration to appear tomorrow— At the Office— Wyer— Elizabeth Cranch went home— Mrs. Adams ill in bed.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.note: Caucus System for Nominating Presidential Candidates

div.p: 7. VII.R. M. Johnson here. Caucus Call and Declaration against it both in the same paper— Genl. Call here— To see papers against Steele. Tomlinson here with Everts, Missionary. G. Hay at the Office. Slave average value papers— Metcalf at the Office— And Henry— At the President’s Cabinet Meeting postponed, Calhoun being unwell. President at the Office— Act of Invitation to La Fayette— H. Baldwin. To see papers against him— Columbian Institute meeting. I attended— Goodacre’s third Lecture— Climates— Miss M’Knight went home. Mrs A. yet ill. Blunt here—

8. VII. Heard Staughton at the Capitol 1. Thess. 5.20. Stranger at Baker’s Psalm 2.11. Little 2. Cor: 5.10. At the President’s A.M. Met Genl. Jackson, Southard, and Mosher there— Invitation to go with them to Church. Met R. Forrest. D. Brent here— Act inviting La Fayette sent to G. Graham’s Office— Visit to the judges— To Mallary. To Bradley. G. Blake here— Letter from G. Fairbanks. Van Wyck here in the eve. Also D’Wolfe and Dodge. Mrs Adams keeps her chamber.

9. VI.Charles A. Wickliffe, for Passports for two persons going to Mexico— William C. Rives— Letter for H. Nelson— Judge W. P. Van Ness for a Court House— At the Office. Eveleth, for a place. Cabinet Meeting. Calhoun and Southard— S. Smith and Lloyd’s Letter. Hayti. Decision. At the Office— Wyer— Genl. Call with Hannum—to see Accounts from St. Augustine. Eve at Goodacre’s 4th. Lecture— Precession of Equinoxes.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.note: Caucus System for Nominating Presidential Candidates

div.p: 10. VI:30.Charles left us for Cambridge— Crowninshield here with Coll. Decatur, for Consulate at Tripoli— White of Kentuckey— Caucus, and dispositions of that State. W. Plumer. His Conversation yesterday with H. G. Burton, one of the signers of the Caucus Summons. Burton’s enquiries— Answered by me. Luckett here with judge Bibb of Kentuckey. At the Office, Baker the Clergyman— First payment on the Note. C. J. Ingersoll from Philadelphia. S. H. Smith with Boyd of New-York, Niles of Baltimore, and Tyson— Evening at Mrs Decaturs. Southard.— Raymond. G. Johnson.

11. VII.Daniel P. Cook here— Paper to be authenticated, Ingham & Rogers talk about the Franklin Gazette— G. Hay, with Slave average value papers. Spoke of James Barbour, but was interrupted.— John King and Pendleton. Visits— J. Crowell of Alabama—Indian Agent— S. Van Wyck— Would be glad to go to Europe, as a diplomatic agent or messenger— At the Office. R. M. Johnson for Luckett and others— Randall—to go to the Havanna. Evening at Goodacre’s 5th. Lecture—the moon— Genl. Winder & Dr Watkins here— Rain-storm.

12. VII.Hodgson came with a Letter to apply for an office. P. Little with two Brown’s and another person from Baltimore County— J. Bailey here with a judge Scott from Ohio. Coll. R. M. Johnson with Letters against Steele at Pensacola— Hanham the Sheriff from St. Augustine, with his accounts— Ingersoll for Documents and Mably— Conquest of Florida. H. G. Burton— Presidential Election— For Crawford. Against Clay. Anxious for a compromise: to secure an Election by the Electors, and keep Clay out of the House— Said he would see Crawford— At the President’s. He will nominate N. Edwards for Mexico— Company to dine— No Ladies.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.note: Caucus System for Nominating Presidential Candidates

div.p: 13. VII.G. Hay here with a Slave average value certificate. He spoke also of a publication in last Evenings Republican against Mr Crawford; and of the excuse in this Morning’s Intelligencer for rejecting it. He thought Mr Crawford’s friends were those who most disserved him— H. G. Burton was here—had seen Crawford, who was hurt at paragraphs in the papers, stating that I had rejected with scorn and indignation the proposal of his friends to vote for me as Vice-President; but had told him that if his friends thought proper to vote for him as Vice-President, and he should be elected, he would accept of that appointment— But the Caucus must be held— Sullivan here— Reasons for not answering W. King— At the Office. Torrens with Note— Mexican Boundary Reynolds— Remission of a fine— J. A. Adams for a Clerkship. Hanham with his Accounts— At the President’s. he directed payment of them. Met Forsyth—wanted to see papers in Mitchell’s case— Dined at Mr Southard’s with 30. Talk with Crowninshield and Eaton— Found Frye when I came home. Johnson Hellen to Rockville—John with him.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.note: Caucus System for Nominating Presidential Candidates

div.p:
14. VII.Dr Thornton called this morning; pressed by delay of his Salary. Mr S. C. Crafts came with a Letter from Governor Van Ness asking a change in the Newspaper Printers of the Laws in Vermont— Must lay over till the next Session— Mr Niles of Baltimore and his Son were here: visiting. Also Mr Hemphill with a Mr Ross, son of James Ross of Pittsburg, and John Reed of Massachusetts with Mr Bates the Collector of Bristol, Rhode-Island. W. Plumer who spoke of his Conversation with Saunders— Jennings of Indiana, who asked for copies of the Correspondence relating to the appointments of Dewey
as district Attorney in that State— At the Office, Crowninshield; spoke of Letters from Sprague, at Salem and the Caucus. Forsyth who saw the papers relating to D. B. Mitchell’s case— Nelson who came concerning certain claims on France, for losses in St. Domingo. Frye; who had heard of a mode of proceeding intended for this Evening; against which, he thought there should be a guard. J. Bailey; recommending Massey— Wyer—preparing to attend the Caucus— Came in the Evening and announced its result— Frye afterwards— 66 votes, of which 62 for W. H. Crawford. 2. for J. Q. Adams. 1. for A. Jackson, and 1 for N. Macon. For A. Gallatin as Vice-President 57.

15. VII. Heard Little A.M. Job. 19.25.26.27.— Selden took me home. A stranger P.M. at Baker’s. James 4.7. G. Sullivan came to talk with me about the claim, and about his position with W. King— John returned from Rockville— G. Blake, Blunt, Mr and Mrs Frye, Achille Murat, J. Sergeant, G. Sullivan and E. Wyer dined with us.

16. VI:30.Keller came this morning about a petition to Congress and a Letter from Doctor Thornton recommending him as keeper of the models— I sent them to L. M’Lane Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means— C. A. Wickliffe a member from Kentucky came and introduced a Mr Triplett— Coll. Dwight, with a claim of a Mr Bliss upon France— C. S. Coxe appointed Consul to Tunis came wishing to be despatched— Dr Everett and S. L. Gouverneur the President’s Son in Law paid a morning visit— There was no Mail. At the President’s with Prevost’s charges against Stewart. Southard came in— Troubled with a refractory Surgeon’s Mate named Phillips. Wyer at the Office— John dined at Mr Selden’s— Mary Hellen and Abigail Adams at Mrs Decatur’s— I called on Coll. Taylor, Senator from Virginia— He is anxiously anti-caucus. At Goodacre’s 7th. Lecture on Comets— Parallax and Saturn.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.note: Caucus System for Nominating Presidential Candidates

div.p:
17. VII.G. Hay called with a Slave average value paper. Captain Isaac Phillips, formerly of U.S. Navy, about his dismission in 1799. a Mr Howe, applying for an Office. J. Barnard with a subscription for a Polyglott Bible— Mr Luckett with a Mr Howland of Loudoun County, Virginia— Mr Hemphill with a judge Reed, and Mr Hall of Pennsylvania. Daniel Davis to take leave, going to-morrow Morning for Boston— T. Fuller here, and Coll R. M. Johnson, who wishes further concert against the Caucus party.
Fuller is for moderation and tranquility— G. Sullivan, brought draft of a Letter to Secy War on the Claim— At the Office— Nevin with a Letter from Lot Clark member from New-York—wanted a Book. Dodge with a Letter of enquiries, about Consular fees— Joaquin Barrozo Pereira, Portuguese Charge d’Affaires brought a credential Letter from the Marquis of Palmella, and desired to be presented in that capacity to the President— Call at the President’s. Will receive Pereira to-morrow. Told me he would send in the nomination of N. Edwards as Minister to Mexico to-morrow— Wyer at the Office— Tuesday Evening party at my house— Very crowded. Mrs Adams ill—not able to attend— Southard spoke to me of the affair between Rodney and Biddle— Sullivan left with me his draft of a Letter to the Secy of War on the claim.

18. VII. Visits from Chief Justice Marshall, and the judges Washington, Johnson, Duval and Story— Also from A. Stewart of Pennsylvania, with a Mr Dawson and Mr Irving. G. Sullivan came. Had been conversing with the President about the claim— He will send it to Congress, strongly recommended— Inflexible on that point. Sullivan’s embarrassment between insisting on the right of the State, and fear of offending the President. I advised him to insist— Weymouth came to ask for employment— At one I presented Pereira, and his Secretary to the President. At the Office. Addington to enquire of news from England— Message, well received there— Not so well in France. Tyler to solicit a place. C. J. Ingersoll; for a packet to him from R. Rush yesterday. Wyer: daily visit. Drawing-room at the President’s— I alone of the family went. Great crowd. Southard had seen the Delaware Senators, about the affair of Rodney and Biddle. Cambreleng’s rage at the nomination of N. Edwards— Father in Law, to a three tail’d Bashaw—spoken to S. L. Gouverneur, at the President’s House—

19. VII.R. M. Johnson here, and introduced a Mr Munro from Kentucky. D. Brent, for a Note to the Slave indemnity Commission— A Mr Strong from Albany, seeking Evidence that James Knowles was a Lieutenant of the Boston frigate in 1777— A Mr Nicholls came to enquire, if he could expect indemnity for a vessel seized in Port in England in 1812. on the breaking out of the War. I thought not. J. Bailey. The Committee of Elections have drawn up their Report against him. Their refusal to enquire into the facts relating to Forsyth’s Election— I said their Report must be founded on prejudice and not on principle— I called at Mr Crawford’s, but he was not at home— At the President’s but he was out. Wyer at the Office. Company to dine— Mrs Adams unwell; and not at table.

20. VII.G. Hay brought a paper on the Slave average value. W. Slade junr. arrived last Evening, and this morning took the Oath as a Clerk in the Department of State— Jacob Waln of Philadelphia came as a visitor, self-introduced. Jos: Blunt, at the Office, going to Philadelphia for some days. Stephen Longfellow, member from Maine, to enquire of astronomical instruments and an Observatory— Henderson, and his Son from S. Carolina concerning the claim for the Heirs of Coll. John Laurens. Call at the President’s with despatch from R. Rush— Canning and Polignac— President spoke of N. Edwards, and Crawford—his conduct in 1813— Fuller at the Office— Bailey’s case. Calhoun abandoned, in Pennsylvania— Dined at Calhoun’s— Livingston’s there. Found Miss Roberdeau, on returning home.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.note: Caucus System for Nominating Presidential Candidates

div.p: 21. VII. Morning visitors N. Macon with a Letter to a Captain Smyth, at St. Thomas’s. R. M. Johnson to repeat the recommendation of Mr Steel as Consul at Acapulco— Opposition to N. Edwards in the Senate. Clay’s sangwine expectations, and probable disappointments. D. P. Cook. His views and intentions. Gallatin— I urged Cook not to bear hard upon him. R. M. Saunders, repeating a recommendation of a Mr Williamson. Roy of Virginia—going to Europe and asks for Letters. H. Fuller—just from Massachusetts— W. Plumer— For appointment of Cogswell as Marshall of New-Hampshire— His Conversations with Hall of North-Carolina— Met going to the Office Mr D’Wolfe, with his Son in Law Hall— D’Wolfe left with me two Letters against Bates. D’Wolfe’s anger against Knight— Knight’s promises when elected S.U.S. non-performance now— Told D’Wolfe if he would not go into Caucus, Bates would not be turned out!— J. A. King— Came from his father— Rumoured interview between P.U.S.Genl. Jackson and Calhoun— Its supposed connection with the nomination of N. Edwards to Mexico. G. M. Dallas’s transfer of the Calhoun standard to Jackson at Philadelphia, and D. P. Cook’s contingent vote in H.R.U.S. fact and fiction blended— Pereira, Portuguese Charge d’Affaires, asking exequatur’s for Vice-Consuls— His demand that we should compel Constancio to give up the funds in his hands— Told him I thought he must go to the tribunals— Blunt—going tomorrow to Philadelphia. J. Bailey— Report of the Committee of Elections against him. Difficulty of getting Forsyth’s case before the House— Company to dine— Genl. HarperD. Lynch—Pendleton, and L. N. Rogers— Evening company. J. A. King Sergeant, Frye’s, Smith’s, Thornton’s, Talbot’s, Baring, Dwight and Miss Davis. Losing Chess with Harper— Music— Miss Davis and Lynch.

bibl.author: JQA
bibl.note: Caucus System for Nominating Presidential Candidates

div.p: 22. VII. Stormy day. Heard Baker. A.M. from Proverbs 14:12. and P.M. from Matthew 11.6. Visit at Georgetown to Forsyth— He gave me a Letter asking one of introduction for W. Bell Rogers, to our official agent at Mexico— Call on R. King who is ill with an inflammatory sore throat— His political views— Has written to N. Edwards, and seen D. P. Cook— Van Buren was offered the Caucus Vice-Presidency, but declined, and proposed the nomination of A. Gallatin. King inclines to R. Rush as Vice-President. L. M’Lane came in— His inquiries as Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means. The Mexican Mission— King says M’Lane’s eye is to a seat on the Bench of the Supreme Court. I was late at afternoon service. Note from G. Sullivan— He came; long conversation with him— P.U.S. has determined to send a Message to Congress recommending payment of the claim— Peirce’s opposition and obstinacy. Crowninshield’s advice— I declined advising on the main point. But recommended that Pearce should have a last option to join in the Letter to P.U.S.

23. VII:15.Crowninshield here— Spoke of the claim. His impression as to the effect of its being sent to Congress— His Conversation with the President. G. Hay with a Slave average value paper— Genl. Call with Coll. Reed from Pensacola— Testifies in favour of W. F. Steele— At the Office Mr Marvin with a friend from the State of New-York. Elkins to explain a demand upon E. Wyer for assorting his shells. Dodge, about his Consular fees at Marseilles. He goes next week— Hollins junr. of Baltimore, for another Letter to Warner to procure papers at the Havanna— At the President’s. Pereira’s application against Constancio. Cannot be complied with— The President sent in the Message concerning the Massachusetts Claim— Opposition in the Senate to the nomination of N. Edwards— Meeting pretended, totally denied by the President. At the Office again— Sullivan. Satisfied with the reception of the claim at H.R. Pearce refused to co-operate— Wyer—to tell me that Hamilton of S. C. had spoken well of me— Spent the Evening in writing. Si Sic Omnia— Addington above— Music— Snow to cover the ground.

24. VII. Visits from Coll. Dwight, with Saltonstall, from Salem; and from H. W. Edwards with a Mr Hubbard, of Connecticut, a Woollen Manufacturer, wishing to introduce certain spinning machinery into Russia— Note from N. Edwards— Papers desired by him not on the Office files— At the Office. Crowell: to enquire concerning Slave indemnities— Webster, with W. Sturgis of Boston. Goodlet, to ask compensation for having carried despatches to Europe, in 1816. Not allowable. C. D. Coxe, going Consul to Tunis, to take leave. Judge Van Ness of New-York— Asks copies of Letters to P.U.S. recommending him for Judge of Supreme Court— Evening at a Ball at Mr Calhoun’s.

25. VII:15.Coll. R. M. Johnson here with a Mr Fisher from Philadelphia. Mr Roy of Virginia; desired me to send the Letters of introduction he had requested to our Ministers in England and France to Gloucester Court House— W. Plumer, about the Letter of the New Hampshire delegation in 1820. concerning the Newspaper printing of the Laws— Raymond of Baltimore; visit with a Mr Lord of New-York. Cobb of Georgia, for the Yazoo Claim certificate— Act of Congress passed for its delivery— Cobb’s animosity against Clay— At the Officefrom Baltimore, about the claim on the Haytian Government— Bernard a Button manufacturer from Baltimore, with a Letter from P. Little, and samples which he gave me— W. King of Maine—going to-morrow— Commissioners adjourned to 1. April— Dined at Baron Tuyll’s, with a mixed party— Evening Ball at Mr T. Peter’s Georgetown— Went with Mary Roberdeau, Abby Adams and John— Chess with L. N. Rogers— Home after midnight— The President was taken ill in the Night last Night. I called to enquire at his house; he was confined to his bed.

26. VII:15. Rain Storm the whole day— Craven P. Luckett, appointed a Commissioner of Land titles in Florida came to say he proposed to go, the next week— Dined yesterday, he says with Agg, Editor of the Washington Republican— Desperate condition of that Establishment— Will go against whomever the Crawford party take up. Bates the Collector of Bristol R.I. was here—defends himself against Mr D’Wolfe’s charges. Says his sin is having suppressed the Slave-trade at Bristol. D’Wolfe had been at the Office yesterday, and renewed his complaints against Bates— I told Bates of the charge of Unitarian partialities, which he disclaimed. Also the case of the seizure, and his refusal to do business out of Office hours. Heard his defence upon both, and promised if asked my opinion by the President to give it impartially— Judge Van Ness applied again for copies of the recommendations of him— I called at the President’s, in his bedchamber, convalescent— Thinks copies can be given only with the consent of the writers— Left with P.U.S. draft of Letter to Governor of Cuba— Wyer at the Office— Company to dine— Judges of Supreme Court and the Bar. Mrs Adams and Mary Roberdeau at table— Mary Hellen unwell— Miss Roberdeau went to a party at General Macomb’s, and then home— I told judge Van Ness of the President’s opinion as to giving copies of Recommendations— He said he had put them all into the President’s hands himself, and thought he had a right to take them back. I advised him to write to P.U.S. He said he thought he would—

27. VII.G. Sullivan here. Read me the copy of a Letter that he has written to Governor Eustis, defending himself against the charges of W. King— He says he has sent at copy of to his father in Law T. L. Winthrop, with directions to have it immediately published without consulting the Governor, who he thinks has dealt unfairly with him by withholding from the Legislature some of his former Letters— He says he knew from an undoubted source, that King’s design was to make the claim an engine to obtain votes for Mr Crawford; but says it is impossible to suppose that Crawford had any knowledge of it— This he told me he had said, out of delicacy to Mr Crawford: but from the facts every one would draw his conclusion— Foot of Connecticut told him he would vote against payment of the claim; for it would be giving a premium to rebellion. Fuller is offended because the Message was sent without consulting him. He told me of some old grudges between Fuller and him; and asked me to appease Fuller— I said I would speak to Fuller; but that he was very independent, and tenacious— At the Office— T. Randall—in preparation to be despatched to the Havanna— Dodge—to leave the City next week, and asked Letters to Mr Brown and General La Fayette— Letter from P. Sharpe with enclosures from Ogilvie. At the President’s—in his bed-chamber; but had been below all the morning. He thought Ogilvie’s request could not be complied with— He claims the Earldom of Findlater in Scotland, with the Estate annexed to the title; and wished the President and Secretary of State and Mr Rush to aid him in pursuit of the claim. The President said it would be ridiculous— He spoke to me of several Letters which had passed in 1817. between General Jackson and him; and read me two of them from Jackson to him, dated in January and 13. March of that year. This correspondence has recently given rise to incidents which he said had occasioned much uneasiness to him— Some weeks since, when General Jackson was becoming a formidable Candidate for the Presidency in Pennsylvania; there appeared a paragraph in the Democratic Press, asserting that he had in 1817 written a Letter to the President, recommending to him to form his Cabinet of two distinguished federalists and two Republicans— This was denied in the Washington Republican as an infamous calumny— Kreamer a member of Congress from Pennsylvania, went to the President, and asked him how it was. The President told him he had received no such Letter from Jackson; but only a Letter recommending Coll. Drayton of South Carolina, a federalist but who had served through the late War, for Secretary of War— Kreamer wrote a Letter to Binns, Editor of the Democratic Press, which was published in that paper, telling of this denial of the President. The charge that such a Letter had been written
was repeated, and that the President had read it to a Senator of U.S. in 1816 and 1817. and the Press added, it was said he had read it to Messrs.Lowry and Findlay, now Senators U.S. from Pennsylvania. Findlay denied this, but Lowry remained silent— The President was then put upon looking up Jackson’s Letters to him; but could not until within these three days find the Letter in controversy— And has not to this day found the copy of his answer to it— Two days since he received a Note from Lowry, informing him that he had received under a blank cover from Richmond, a copy of this answer— The President said he had no doubt that the copy came from elsewhere, and had been first sent to Richmond to have the appearance of being transmitted from thence. I told him I thought it probably came from Roberts or Lacock, and he said that was his own belief— He then told me the occasion of his great confidence in those two men during the late War— His misunderstandings with Armstrong, and their catastrophe— The wrangling two years ago, about the re-nomination of Irish as Marshal of the Western District of Pennsylvania— And that was the occasion upon which he spoke to Lourie, and Findlay of Jackson’s Letter to him, but did not read it— But how the Copy of his own answer was obtained, and by whom, he knew not. Nor what were Lowry’s intentions— But if he meant to bargain with him, he would be disappointed— He said it had been a great indiscretion in him to read to those persons Jackson’s Letter to him; but it was when he had not a conception that Jackson would be a Candidate for the Presidency, and Jackson now declared that he would be perfectly satisfied that every thing he had ever written him should be published— I told the President that Judge Van Ness claimed the Recommendations of him as judge of the Supreme Court, on the ground of his having delivered them himself to him— He said it was so of some of them. I thought this at variance with the Letter of his brother General J. P. Van Ness inclosing some of the recommendations; alledging that they were not known to the Judge, who declined such assistance as not necessary for him. The President said Judge Van Ness could not reconcile his mind to the disappointment of failing to obtain the appointment. That he the President had told him that though he himself had no suspicion of the judge’s being implicated in Rudd’s delinquency, he had suffered
a prejudice to grow up against him, by not meeting insinuations of a Committee of Congress, by a formal demand of investigation— So that the nomination of him would have been endangered in Senate: While I was with the President, Mr Southard came in upon Navy Department business. I dined at Mr Wirt’s. Mrs Adams did not go. Mixed company; part diplomatic. Answered P. Sharpe’s Letter— Home past nine— Mary Hellen and John unwell.

28. VII.Dr Thornton here. Coll. Constant Freeman. 4th. Auditor died last Night. The Dr. applies for his place, and brought me a dissertation upon Comets— A young man heretofore recommended by the Post-master General M’Lean came to apply again for employment in the Department of State, or an appointment as Secretary of Legation abroad. A RevdMr Croes came to solicit a subscription for the episcopal Theological Seminary— Told him I had subscribed before— He then shewed me a book, with my name on it as a subscriber for 50 dollars, together with many other names, all of them with the mark “paid” except mine— I told him, I was confident I had paid—and he said—“to Mr Carter”— He asked if I would not subscribe again— I declined— And after he was gone found by my check book that I had paid the subscription to a Mr Carter— J. Bailey was here. Conduct of Sloane, Chairman of the Committee of Elections to him. Told him he should move to call up the Report next Monday— Sloane has reported my Statement and answers, without his own Letters and the questions of the Committee to which they were answers— Judge Thruston here. His own unhappy disease— His Son now suffering from sleeplessness. To be indulged with relaxation— General Call came; about the accounts from Pensacola. Mr Pedersen with a Mr Brandis, attached to the Danish Legation— Mr Farrelly of Pennsylvania, to solicit the appointment of fourth Auditor for General Alden— Words in the House yesterday between Ingham and P. P. Barbour, with Archer— At the Office— Theodore Newells Orrery or Planetarium— Mr Parrott of New Hampshire, about a claim of Reuben Shapleigh— Richards, Delegate from Michigan, concerning the case of M’Donnell, to obtain a reversal of outlawry in Canada; and a road from Detroit to Chicago— But he is afraid to propose the road to the Committee himself, and wishes it to come from the Executive— Wyer made his daily visit— I received a new Letter from J. Sloane, Chairman of the Committee of Elections— About Forsyth’s case, without naming him. Evening at home, writing.

29. VII. Heard Mr Little A.M. from 1. Timothy 2.5. “For there is one God, and one mediator between God and man, the man Christ Jesus.” A strong, and explicit unitarian text, but leaving the controversy just where it was— In the afternoon Mr Baker from Psalm 12.4—“our lips are our own: Who is lord over us?” a remarkable text, susceptible of various application. After the morning services I called to see Mr N. Edwards of Illinois. Found J. B. Thomas his Colleague, and D. P. Cook with him— Edwards is confined with an intermittent fever— Thomas soon went away. Edwards spoke of his nomination to Mexico. Confident of the support of the Senate. Of Mr R. King’s friendly proceedings. Of his own threats to Gales and Seaton— Of his offices in Kentucky. Of his Conversation with Calhoun, since Dallas’s desertion of him, which Edwards says was entirely unexpected to Calhoun, and without concert with the Pennsylvania members here— Which I do not believe— But Calhoun he says will take no part in giving their next direction to his friends—quite probable. The Count de Menou came in, and I came away— Eve at home, writing—

Day. Rise at 7. Write or read a little till 9–10. Breakfast—write or receive visitors till 1–2. At the Office— Mail—at the President’s, and visitors till 5–6. Home and dine— Evening abroad or with company at home, about five Evening’s in the week— The other two, read newspapers or write till 11–12 and then to bed.
